comments.commentBody:
"A bewildered Chinese friend asked me how the world’s leading democracy could be so mismanaged that it could shut down. I couldn’t explain."
Sometimes I wonder, do I (or we) love democracy so much that we will keeping on loving it even when its practitioners act like spoiled, destructive teenagers? Or will we be attracted to some other form of government (enlightened despotism)? After all, for something (or someone, like a politician in Washington) to be loved, it/he/she must be lovable. Some years down the road, will we, like the citizens of late Republican Rome, be looking for a Caesar? We'd better think about this seriously because even in democratic America, there are Caesars waiting in the wings.

A large part of the problem is that the very wealthy and connected have insulated themselves completely from the consequences of their own decisions and indecisions, and the media doesn't hold them accountable in the slightest. I rarely hear them called to task for their repeated calls for middle class sacrifices that they themselves refuse to take.

They live in enclaves surrounded by the privileged; most send their children to elite private schools or cherry picked public schools, so even their children are insulated. Budget shortages for schools? Who cares? THEIR children go to private! A high rate of unemployment? Not for them! THEIR jobs are not only filled with perks and a juicy pension (that they attack in the regular folk), but in addition, they are pretty much guaranteed the golden revolving door between political life and business, no matter how crappy a job they do. Jobs outsourced? Not theirs! Health insurance premiums too high or unattainable? Not theirs--WE pay for them, best of the best! Wars that go on forever, paid for in our children's lives? Not THEIR children!

I know several people who have been miserable these past few weeks in case of a government shut down. Hardworking people who wouldn't know how to pay their mortgage or put food on the table. Yet these clowns go on with their narcissistic posturing, secure in the knowledge it will never touch THEM. The media needs to call them to task. SOMEONE needs to out these hypocrites.

If the government ever does shut down, the FIRST people it should affect are the politicians who are failing their jobs--no salary at all for them, no perks, until they actually do the job they were hired to do: Represent the American people and our country.

I am impressed by the insights of your readers and am actually learning quite a bit about sharia. I appreciate many of them standing up for their religion and coming out against the incidents that took place. I feel a similar level of anger towards the pastor in FL being a dumbass in the name of Jesus Christ and frankly, the United States. It is hard to feel that others are represented your culture in a terrible way, especially to the rest of the world. I am so heartbroken for this little girl and her family.

Let's all think of a way we can do something positive to impact our world around us today in her honor.

You correctly praise Congressman Ryan's courage in taking on entitlements. But I think you are wrong when you state that the Democrats haven’t had the guts to deal with entitlements seriously.  I believe it is much worse than cowardice: the Democrats are well aware of the hole that those entitlement programs are digging for future generations, but they care more about doing well for themselves in the next election. The Democrats in Congress have intentionally avoided even bringing up the possibility of trimming the entitlement programs in hopes that the Republicans would, thereby allowing the Democrats to posture as the "protectors" of the very programs that are bankrupting us. The truly sad thing is, I suspect the strategy will likely work, particularly in places with a sizable senior population like Florida. If so, we will truly end up with the Congress we deserve.
You've got to hand it to the Tea Party.  Despite little to no congressional experience, it took its elected members only three months to shut down the United States government..  Almost.

The thing is nick, is there any country on this planet here everyone is happy with their government and law makers? The lucky few who have a democracy, have to live with debates, negotiations, compromise, which is a good thing actually, no matter how messy it may seem. We have to remember we are one country, each of us might not fully agree with one another, or where the country is going, or how the lawmakers do business, or how mean spirited and belligerent they might seem. But we all love our country and together we will get through it. For the republican proposed budget to work, they will need full support of the democrats, they cannot execute it on their own. And the reverse is true as well. Let's all calm down, roll up our sleeves and get to work. We have to show our children we care.

Nick, you should explain to yuor Chinese friends that it's the intention of a substantial group of our leaders, legislators and judges to bring the United States back to the year one and then begin all over again with a "different approach". . I think he'll get the connection.

In your April 9 column, you take the Democrats to task for not passing a budget while they had a majority in the House. The problem was a filibuster in the Senate. The Democrats did the best they could while the Republicans had 41 votes in the Senate. Remember that the passage of the continuing resolution in December was only by virtue of "buying off" the REpublicans by giving them the two year extension of the Bush tax cuts, Not a fair critique to say that the Dems should have passed something that the Senate Republicans wouldn't allow.

A word to pundits: Please stop calling Paul Ryan or his budget plan "courageous". So it dismantles social programs like Medicare and expands the income inequality even more with reducing taxes for the rich, but that's not courageous, it's just what the Koch brothers and right-wing think tanks have been pushing for years.
re: "Our Cowardly Congress":  Amen, Brother Nicholas.   The Democrats do not have what it takes to get the job done, and the GOP is a nightmare.    We are done.

In my opinion, the Big Picture is about redistribution of income. Entitlement programs do that, but they are open ended. So, the lawyers in congress see a "slippery slope". The ones who can count, ask how much do I pay and how much do I get back? If you are poor, you get back more than you pay. Otherwise it is the other way around. In addition, average Joe does not know how to count and also does not see what he gets for his taxes. On top of all that, the world is changing so fast that average Joe is scared. So it is easy to blame "government bureaucrats" for all our troubles and vote for those who shout "shut it down".
Do you think we should be optimistic?

I now believe that the only way we rid ourselves of this essentially dysfunctional government at federal and state levels is a national calamity of some sort that is so devastating that it either brings everyone together, or somehow destroys the political system we have for a fresh start with something else.  This foundering two-party system is more than entrenched; it is a stinking cesspool of corruption, legalized bribery, self dealing and cronyism, hypocrisy, with a revolving door of polticians and lobbyists who actually now write most legislation.  The Supreme Court is packed with corporatists that have given corporations carte blanche to essentially write out laws, the general public be damned.  Polticians spend more time on cable shows yelling at the other side than doing their work.  The level of discourse is beyond low, it is feckless to the point of absurdity.  I have had conversations with some folks where actually leaving the US to live elsewhere has become a real topic of conversation.  At some point, the Egyptians had enough of Mubarak.  At some point, we will have had enough of these lunatics running our country.  By then, though, they may have ruined it beyond repair....

Of course you are exactly right about the budget, but one query regarding the tigers at the National Zoo:  Does the National Zoo now have an admission fee?  It never did when I was a kid and when my kids were kids.

Okay, you mean "our lovable government" ironically -- I think I can understand why.  But from my point of view, one of the major stones unturned is actually how to love these folks, their constituents, and the press that follows them, or rather, how to get them to feel love not with the sink-holes within their egos but with some other aspect of their personalities.  For example, maybe they need to be praised for something that makes them stop needing approbation through cheap shots at each other.  If that's what they get positive feedback for, it would explain the habit.  So, my thinking is that if we all, including columnists and audience, are part of this relationship that also includes our politicians and other government officials, maybe if we do something different ourselves in our part of the relationship, something new will develop in the dynamic overall, and maybe our politicians and government will also end up behaving differently as they respond to a new dynamic.  I guess my own inclination is to try to express acceptance on some basic level while agreeing or disagreeing with their positions and behavior.
The only thing worse than spineless politicians are weepy liberal pundits who don't think the federal government can ever spend enough.
How dare you describe "Mr. Ryan" as "courageous"? Is that the new euphemism for sociopathy? Have you no shame or no cortical convolutions remaining?

The budget fiasco is but one minor scene in a much larger drama, one symptom among many. Examples abound: pay twice the percentage of GNP for medical care as Europe, get inferior results -- no cure can be found. Rapidly declining results from public education, an omen for what future I wonder. A trade deficit with no end visible--the Upper Midwest a graveyard of once-productive factories, shuttered, empty, idle. Sarah Palin or Michelle Bachmann discussed as presidential candidates of one of the two viable parties? Tragedy has become comedy. Clearly, government has already receded to the point where the kleptocracy wants it to be: bought 'n' paid for, irrelevant, dysfunctional, downright silly. Next thing we know, C-Span will be showing the House in live session on Saturday night...live!

There is no single, simple answer; no obvious cure; and very likely, no going back. What was lost is .... lost. In 2008, we thought we could. Now? Doubt replaces Hope. I weep for my country that once was.

Mr. Kristof -

The last sentence of your commentary reads:

"This budget war reflects inanity, incompetence and cowardice that are sadly inexplicable."

It is this point that we all seem to be missing. In effect, what is it that is causing such a feeble and incompetent level of behavior? What is it about the human condition?

There seems to be fundamental factors and dynamics at play that if we fail to recognize will continually haunt us. In effect, what is driving this inanity?

Your thoughts.

This particular congress proves that education is severely needed in this country... an education in morality and ethics (and mathematics)! Listening to modern political candidates, it is clear that these people are under the delusion that the people are asking for a return to early 19-century standards. These "people" (and I use this term loosely) give humanity a bad name, and even make carnivorous wildlife look cute.

We citizens are a little busy trying to maintain any semblance of a normal life, and we have Congress and the moneyed interests to thank for our lot in life. We're all waiting for an apology for your utter ignorance and greed! And PLEASE hold your breaths until we all feel that time is right to accept it. You'd be doing the rest of us a big favor if you would just pass out indefinitely so that the rest of us can get back to the real work of strengthening our democracy! Both liberal and conservative viewpoints can co-exist in a logical and mature manner. People just need to grow up.

Another well written piece, Mr. Kristof!

Please at least run your column through a spell checker. ;-)

"Sadl, this crisis was only the first act in at least a three-act play."

Good column Nick. Just FYI everyone, I am half of chapter 8 in Nick and Sheryl's Half the Sky: Jane Roberts and her 34 Million Friends. 34 Million Friends means friends of the United Nations Population Fund and thereby of the women of the world. UNFPA, which the Republican House wants to defund for false and spurious reaons, prevents more abortions with its family planning programs all over the world than all the admonitions of all the "pro-life" people combinedl. To be honest, a very significant proportion are against family planning, and at a deep level are against gender equality. They would have the U.S. not join the entire world community in supporting UNFPA. This is unconscionable and very very ugly. Please join 34 Million Friends. It's our super fantastic grassroots movement for the women of the world. www.34millionfriends.org Big Cheers, Jane

Yes, DC's (National) Zoo is free, but the District is not -- and this last round on the Hill is further reducing the rights of its citizens to spend their own taxes as they choose, including for abortion assistance for low-income women. (It's OK, however, to spend on Boehner's beloved vouchers,
to further undermine public education....) Ah, NK, invest in asprin or your preferred headache (and stomach ache) remedies: it's going to be worse yet, while our president gives away more and more services from and capacity in the national governmen.

Nick, you are right , but don't the voters who put these fools in charge bear the true responsibility? We the people are to blame when someone like Trump is actually considered a presidential candidate.

This Congress is beyond dysfunctional. To qutoe Gunnery Sergeant Highway (Clint Eastwood) in "Heartbreak Ridge", "it's a cluster f--k, SIR". Perhaps that's too rude for many people, but it's as close to fact as can be. This group doesn't deserve re-election; they deserve to be recalled. What they call "just politics" or horse-trading in my world is called extortion.
Everyone knows that the Federal deficit is montrous problem and needs to be attacked immediately. But even threatening to solve it, just partially, by shutting down the government is unconscionable. Send this whole bunch of lawyers back home to chase after ambulances.
Am I angry? You bet. But my anger is nothing like that of the American soldiers who found out the hard way that they were just pawns in a giant crooked chess game. In the end, no one was "watching theirs backs" back home.

How strange that your Chinese friend would refer to the USA as 'the world's leading democracy'. The USA leads the world in very little nowadays except gun ownership, military expenditure and crime.
Educational competence has greatly declined and the USA is now a fascist state, which Mussolini defined as a corporate state. Those few of us in Europe, Canada and Australia (I am a dual British/Canadian with US PhD who lives in Oz) who once admired the USA, though not so much for its democracy, are sorry to see the precipitous US decline in world standing. I guess that by Chinese standards you are still a democracy though.
